title: Ashes 2015: Darren Lehmann says sorry for heavy defeat | The
text:
AUSTRALIA coach Darren Lehmann has penned a brutally honest column in which he apologises on behalf of the team for its horror Ashes defeat.
Lehmann has already admitted he and his fellow selectors made several mistakes throughout the tour, including selecting Shaun Marsh ahead of his brother Mitchell for the fourth Test at Trent Bridge.
That match, not just the selection, proved to be a disaster as Australia was bowled out for 60 on its way to a chastening innings and 78-run defeat that saw England regain the Ashes.
Given the Aussies entered the series as red-hot favourites, the fact they now find themselves down 3-1 in the series has led to some serious soul-searching.
And it prompted Lehmann to issue a heartfelt public apology.
GOING HOME: HADDIN LEAVES ASHES TOUR
HARRIS: ANGER WITHIN AUSSIE SQUAD OVER RIFT RUMOURS
ANALYSIS: IS AUSTRALIA FACING A MASS CLEAN-OUT?
Australia coach Darren Lehmann (L) talks to captain Michael Clarke. Source: AFP
“We have been poor, we have been outplayed by a superior opponent, and as coaching staff, players and selectors we fully accept the blame for our losses at Edgbaston and Trent Bridge,” Lehmann wrote on Cricket Australia’s website.
“We don’t walk away from that responsibility, and we have been as up-front as we can over the past few days to explain that’s the case rather than try to find excuses.
“Not only do we want to be accountable for our efforts, but on behalf of our team I want to apologise for the manner in which we have lost, especially to those tour groups and individual fans who paid to travel to the UK to watch us and to the millions more tuning in at home.”
While Lehmann said he and his squad were comfortable with accepting criticism for their performances, he wasn’t ready to accept cries from some sections of the media that having players’ families on tour has been a distraction.
Darren Lehmann: 'Selections were wrong' 0:58 Play video
Cricket: Australian coach Darren Lehmann admits he and Rod Marsh got squad selections wrong following Australia's embarrassing Ashes series
Fox Sports 10 Aug 2015 Sport/Cricket/Ashes “As a group, we have always placed a huge importance on family and while we’re happy to cop criticism for the way we bat, bowl, field or prepare I believe it’s unfair to suggest having families with us as a reason for our on-field efforts,” Lehmann wrote.
Lehmann himself was caught in a social media storm after appealing to the Twittersphere for tickets to an English Premier League match, on what would have been day four of the Trent Bridge Test.
The 45-year-old eventually got his wish, but he also received a barrage of abuse from upset Australian fans who suggested he should have spent the time training the players.

— Darren Lehmann (@darren_lehmann) August 8, 2015 Thanks so much for the abuse was asking a question that people might help . Don't bother now! Thanks again people for being so abusive.
— Darren Lehmann (@darren_lehmann) August 8, 2015 What a day thanks @stoke city. Go well .Go the Potters. pic.twitter.com/YLWyWfvE9m
— Darren Lehmann (@darren_lehmann) August 9, 2015 “Even on the occasions when we’ve lost Test matches in three days, I don’t see the value of scheduling extra training sessions,” Lehmann wrote.
“I can assure you the guys have trained as well as I’ve seen during the course of this tour but we just haven’t been able to show that under the pressure of a game and I believe that flogging them with extra training day in, day out would just have a detrimental effect.”
Unsurprisingly Lehmann leapt to the defence of outgoing captain Michael Clarke, pleading with the media to give him the send off he deserves after such a long career.
“Michael deserves the chance to go out with the respect and dignity that he has undoubtedly earned over a fantastic career, and I want to see that career suitably celebrated,” Lehmann wrote.
Originally published as Lehmann’s brutally honest Ashes apology
